title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: What is real? How do we know what we know? What does it mean to be good? This course tackles the biggest questions in life, introducing you to the foundational ideas of the world's greatest thinkers.

lessons.title: What is Philosophy? Metaphysics and Epistemology
lessons.description: Define philosophy and identify the two core branches: Metaphysics and Epistemology.

items: Define philosophy as the love of wisdom and the study of fundamental questions.
Identify the two core branches: Metaphysics (the study of reality) and Epistemology (the study of knowledge).
Understand the difference between a philosophical question and a scientific one.

sections.content: Philosophy, from the Greek 'philosophia', literally means 'love of wisdom'. It is the systematic study of the most fundamental questions about existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language. While science asks 'how' the universe works, philosophy often asks 'why' it works the way it does, or what it means for us. It challenges our most basic assumptions and teaches us how to think more clearly and critically.

Metaphysics: This is the study of the nature of reality. It asks questions like: What is real? What is the relationship between mind and matter? Do we have free will? Is there a God? It explores the fundamental structure of existence itself.

Epistemology: This is the theory of knowledge. It asks: What does it mean to 'know' something? How do we acquire knowledge? Can we ever be certain of anything? It explores the difference between belief, opinion, and justified, true knowledge.

sections.question: The branch of philosophy that studies the nature of reality is called...?
sections.explanation: Remember, Metaphysics deals with reality, while Epistemology deals with knowledge.

lessons.title: Logic and Argument
lessons.description: Define logic as the study of reasoning and differentiate between types of arguments.

items: Define logic as the study of reasoning.
Differentiate between deductive and inductive arguments.

sections.content: Logic is the essential tool that philosophers use to construct and evaluate arguments. An argument in philosophy isn't a heated dispute; it's a set of statements (premises) that are offered as reasons for another statement (the conclusion). Logic provides the rules for determining whether the conclusion truly follows from the premises.
Deductive Arguments: These aim to provide conclusive proof. If the premises are true, the conclusion MUST be true. (e.g., All men are mortal. Socrates is a man. Therefore, Socrates is mortal.)

Inductive Arguments: These aim to provide probable support. The premises make the conclusion likely, but not guaranteed. (e.g., The sun has risen every day in the past. Therefore, the sun will rise tomorrow.)
Logical Fallacies: These are common errors in reasoning that weaken an argument, such as an 'ad hominem' attack, which attacks the person making the argument instead of the argument itself.

sections.question: An argument that aims for a guaranteed, certain conclusion is called...?
sections.explanation: Remember, Deductive arguments aim for certainty.

lessons.title: Plato and the World of Forms
lessons.description: Explore Plato's Theory of Forms and the Allegory of the Cave.

items: Identify Plato as a foundational figure in Western philosophy.
Understand the Allegory of the Cave.

sections.content: Plato, a student of Socrates, believed that the physical world we perceive with our senses is not the real world; it is merely a shadow or imperfect copy of a higher, eternal, and unchanging reality called the World of Forms. For Plato, there is a perfect 'Form' of Justice, a perfect 'Form' of Beauty, and even a perfect 'Form' of a Chair. The things we see in our world are just pale imitations of these perfect Forms.

To explain this, Plato used the Allegory of the Cave. He imagined prisoners chained in a cave, able to see only shadows projected on a wall. They believe these shadows are reality. If one prisoner escapes into the outside world, they see the true objects (the Forms) and the sun (the Form of the Good). When they return to the cave to tell the others, they are not believed. For Plato, the philosopher is like the escaped prisoner, seeking to understand the true nature of reality beyond mere appearances.

sections.question: In Plato's Allegory of the Cave, what do the shadows on the wall represent?
sections.explanation: Remember, the shadows are the imperfect copies, not the true reality.

lessons.title: Aristotle and Empirical Observation
lessons.description: Understand Aristotle's focus on empiricism and the concept of telos.

items: Identify Aristotle as a student of Plato who diverged from his teacher's ideas.
Understand Aristotle's focus on empiricism and the natural world.
Define the concept of 'telos' or purpose.

sections.content: The World is Here and Now

While Plato looked to a higher, abstract world for truth, his student Aristotle was deeply interested in the physical world right in front of us. Aristotle was an empiricist, meaning he believed that knowledge comes from observation and experience. He systematically studied biology, physics, ethics, and politics by observing the world around him. For Aristotle, the 'form' of a thing was not in some other world, but inherent within the object itself.

A core concept for Aristotle is 'telos', which means end, purpose, or goal. He believed everything in nature has a purpose. The telos of an acorn is to become an oak tree. The telos of a human being, he argued, is to achieve 'eudaimonia'—a state of flourishing or living well. We achieve this by cultivating virtues (like courage, temperance, and justice) and living a life of reason.

sections.question: The belief that knowledge comes from observation and experience is called...?
sections.explanation: Remember, Aristotle was the great observer of the natural world.

lessons.title: Ethics - What is the Right Thing to Do?
lessons.description: Differentiate between Utilitarianism and Deontology as ethical frameworks.

items: Define ethics as the branch of philosophy concerning moral principles.
Apply these ethical frameworks to a simple moral dilemma.

sections.content: Ethics, or moral philosophy, explores questions of right and wrong. It's not just about what people *do* believe is right, but what *should* be considered right. Philosophers have developed several major frameworks to guide moral reasoning.

Utilitarianism: Championed by thinkers like Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill, this is a consequentialist theory. It states that the morally right action is the one that produces the greatest good for the greatest number of people. The consequences of the action are what matter.

Deontology: Associated with Immanuel Kant, this theory argues that certain actions are inherently right or wrong, regardless of their consequences. Morality is based on duty and following universal moral rules. For Kant, you should never lie, even if lying might produce a good outcome.

sections.question: Which ethical theory focuses on the consequences of an action to determine if it's right?
sections.explanation: Remember, Utilitarianism is all about the 'utility' or outcome of an action.

lessons.title: Existentialism - Freedom and Responsibility
lessons.description: Explore existentialist philosophy and the concept that existence precedes essence.

items: Define existentialism as a philosophy focused on individual freedom and responsibility.
Understand Jean-Paul Sartre's concept that 'existence precedes essence'.
Explore the ideas of radical freedom and creating one's own meaning.

sections.content: Existentialism, a major 20th-century philosophy, puts the individual at the center. Thinkers like Jean-Paul Sartre argued that for humans, 'existence precedes essence'. This means that we are born without a pre-defined purpose or nature. We simply exist first. It is then up to us, through our choices and actions, to create our own 'essence'—our own meaning and purpose in a meaningless world.

This leads to the idea of 'radical freedom'. We are completely free to choose who we become. However, this freedom comes with a heavy burden of responsibility. We are responsible for everything we do and, in a sense, for creating our own values. This can cause 'existential angst' or dread, but it is also what makes human life uniquely meaningful.

sections.question: The idea that we are born without a pre-defined purpose is summarized by the phrase...
options: The greatest good for the greatest number
sections.explanation: This is Sartre's famous phrase that puts existence before any pre-determined 'essence' or purpose.
